Why: We're not in Kansas anymore

Why: We're not in Kansas anymore Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(3) Systems vs. Ecosystems

  • Software today oftentimes uses external components
  • Systems imply control over all components
    • Change radius is the entire system and changes can be coordinated
  • Ecosystems imply decentralized and uncoordinated control
    • Change radius are components and changes must be absorbed by the design


Why: We're not in Kansas anymore Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(4) Programming-in-the-Huge

Source: Frank DeRemer and Hans Kron, "Programming-in-the-Large versus Programming-in-the-Small", ACM SIGPLAN Notices, Volume 10, Issue 6, Pages 114-121, April 1975



Why: We're not in Kansas anymore Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(5) APIs as Component Interfaces

  • Private APIs are used within organizations
    • Some APIs may be internal to building systems
    • Organizations are ecosystems of various individual systems
  • Partner APIs
    • Established and managed relationships but local autonomy
  • Public APIs
    • Large-scale relationships with little mutual coordination


What: Robustness in Ecosystems

Outline (What: Robustness in Ecosystems)

  2. What: Robustness in Ecosystems [3]

  6. Conclusions [2]
What: Robustness in Ecosystems Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(7) Loose Coupling

  • Coupling always is a trade-off
  • Tight coupling allows for runtime optimizations
  • Loose coupling makes it easier to change things independently
  • Decentralized scenarios are a good candidate for loose coupling
  • Changing things without breaking things is what we're all after


What: Robustness in Ecosystems Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(8) The Value of Loose Coupling

  • Loosely coupled Private APIs mean faster flow of delivery
    • You're powering your business with APIs
  • Loosely coupled Partner APIs mean better partner focus
    • You're augmenting your business with APIs
  • Loosely coupled Public APIs mean better product management
    • The API is (part of) your business


What: Robustness in Ecosystems Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(9) The Risk of Loose Coupling

  • Hard to retrofit (requires culture and training)
  • Constrained evolution (evolves in predicted direction)
  • Innovator's Dilemma (missing disruptive opportunities)

(11) Sweat and Tears



How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(12) Backward and Forward Compatibility



How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(13) Semantic Versioning

  • Semantic Versioning [http://semver.org/] standardizes the meaning of version numbers
  • Version numbers use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH syntax and have well-defined semantics
    • Increase MAJOR version for breaking API changes
    • Increase MINOR version for adding functionality in a forward-compatible manner
    • Increase PATCH version for making forward-compatible bug fixes
  • MAJOR is a different API, PATCH is an implementation detail
    • Exposing detailed version/patch information is a potential security risk
    • For well-designed APIs only MINOR may make sense to expose


How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(14) Semantic Versioning Example



How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(15) Non-Breaking Changes

  1. Add new optional query parameters
  2. Introduce new endpoints without altering existing ones
  3. Add new fields to responses while keeping existing fields unchanged
  4. Include new HTTP headers that clients can choose to use
  5. Provide additional media types via content negotiation
  6. Add new status codes for specific cases without replacing current ones
  7. Allow new values for existing enum fields
  8. Expand existing arrays or collections with additional optional items
  9. Introduce new relationships or links in hypermedia APIs
  10. Offer alternative authentication or authorization methods


How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(16) Compatibility, Take 1



How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(17) Compatibility, Take 2

  • Additions: Only where allowed and must be safe to ignore
  • Semantic Stability: Meaning stays stable and no semantic cross-talk
  • Narrowing Constraints: Types can be changed to subtypes


How: Managing Compatibility Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(18) Don't Don't Version

  • Never changing anything is not a great product management attitude
  • Changes ideally are non-breaking but still are relevant to consumers
  • Give consumers as much freedom as possible to ignore changes
  • Give consumers clear avenues to see and explore changes

(21) Mario's Menu 

{ "menu": {
    "version": "1.0",
    "name": "Mario",
    "food": [
      {
        "name": "Pizza",
        "options": [ "Olives", "Sardelles" ]
      },
      {
        "name": "Pasta",
        "options": [ "Pomodoro", "Carbonara" ]
      }
    ]
  }
}
  • mario-1-0.json


API Evolution in Action Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(22) Checking Mario's Menu: YAML 

"$schema": https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema
type: object
properties:
  menu:
    type: object
    properties:
      version:
        type: string
      name:
        type: string
      food:
        type: array
        items:
          type: object
          properties:
            name:
              type: string
              enum:
              - Pizza
              - Pasta
            options:
              type: array
              items:
                type: string
  • menu-1-0-schema.yaml


API Evolution in Action Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(23) Checking Mario's Menu: JSON 

{ "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
  "type": "object",
  "properties": { "menu": {
    "type": "object",
    "properties": {
      "version": { "type" : "string" },
      "name": { "type" : "string" },
      "food": {
        "type": "array",
        "items": {
          "type": "object",
          "properties": {
            "name": {
              "type": "string", "enum": [ "Pizza", "Pasta" ] },
            "options": {
              "type": "array", "items" : { "type" : "string" } }}}}}}}}
  • menu-1-0-schema.json

(25) A Bigger Menu 

{ "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
  "type": "object",
  "properties": { "menu": {
    "type": "object",
    "properties": {
      "version": { "type" : "string" },
      "name": { "type" : "string" },
      "food": {
        "type": "array",
        "items": {
          "type": "object",
          "properties": {
            "name": {
              "type": "string", "enum": [ "Pizza", "Pasta" , "Risotto" ] },
            "options": {
              "type": "array", "items" : { "type" : "string" } }}}}}}}}
  • menu-1-1-schema.json

      },
      {

        "options": [ "Pomodoro", "Carbonara" ]
      },
      {
        "name": "Risotto",
        "options": [ "Funghi", "Zucca" ]
      }

}

Documenting Versioning

Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(34) Version Identification

  • Indicate the version in interactions
  • Don't break identity between compatible versions
    • Don't make non-major version information part of resource identity
    • Do make major version information part of resource identity
  • Various choices when it comes to representing version information
    • DNS Domain Name: https://v1.api.example.com/
    • URI root: https://api.example.com/v1/
    • Query parameter: https://api.example.com/?version=1.0
    • HTTP header field: API-Version: 1.0
    • Media Type: Content-Type: application/vnd.example.v1+json
    • Media Type: Content-Type: application/vnd.example+json; version=1.0


Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(35) API Versions in OpenAPI

  • OpenAPI does not support representing API version information
  • info.version [https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.1.1.html#fixed-fields-0] represents the version of the API description
  • Consider using x-api-version in your OpenAPI description


Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(36) Versioning & Platform Engineering

  • Clearly an issue for all teams that could/should be pushed into the platform
  • Existing and good API descriptions make documentation much easier
  • oasdiff [https://github.com/Tufin/oasdiff] is a diff tool for OpenAPI descriptions
    • Detects breaking changes based on a configurable model of compatibility
    • Generates changelogs that document and classify changes across versions


Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(37) Formalizing Breaking Changes



Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(38) Changelog in Markdown (also: Text, JSON, YAML, …) 

# API Changelog 1.0.0 vs. 1.0.1

## GET /api/{domain}/{project}/badges/security-score
- :warning: removed the success response with the status '200'
- :warning: removed the success response with the status '201'
- :warning: deleted the 'cookie' request parameter 'test'
- :warning: deleted the 'header' request parameter 'user'
- :warning: deleted the 'query' request parameter 'filter'
-  api operation id 'GetSecurityScores' removed and replaced with 'GetSecurityScore'
-  api tag 'security' removed
-  for the 'query' request parameter 'token', the maxLength was increased from '29' to '30'
-  removed the pattern '^(?:[\w-./:]+)$' from the 'query' request parameter 'image'
-  for the 'query' request parameter 'image', the type/format was generalized from 'string'/'general string' to ''/''
-  removed the non-success response with the status '400'


## GET /api/{domain}/{project}/install-command
- :warning: deleted the 'header' request parameter 'network-policies'
-  added the new optional 'header' request parameter 'name' to all path's operations
-  added the new enum value 'test1' to the 'path' request parameter 'project'


## POST /register
-  the endpoint scheme security 'bearerAuth' was removed from the API
-  the security scope 'write:pets' was added to the endpoint's security scheme 'OAuth'
  • oasdiff-changelog.md


Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(39) Changelog in HTML



Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(40) MongoDB Atlas Changelog: JSON 

  {
    "date": "2024-11-13",
    "paths": [
      {
        "path": "/api/atlas/v2/groups",
        "httpMethod": "GET",
        "versions": [{
          "version": "2024-10-23",
          "changes": [{
            "change": "the 'withDefaultAlertsSettings' response's property default value 'true' was added",
            "changeCode": "response-property-default-value-added",
            "backwardCompatible": true
          }],
          "stabilityLevel": "stable",
          "changeType": "update"
        }],
        "operationId": "listProjects",
        "tag": "Projects"
      },
  • atlas-changelog.json (line 39-57)


Documenting Versioning Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(41) Add Examples

  • Add examples that contain (fictitious) extensions
  • Use a consistent naming scheme for names and values
  • OpenAPI supports adding examples as part of the description
  • Use extensions in your test and validation suites
      {
        "name": "xyzxyz",
        "options": [ "xyzxyz", "xyzxyz" ]
      }
  • menu-1-0-example.json (line 13-16)

Conclusions Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation

(43) What Why When Versioning Matters

  • What: Versioning that's sensitive to breaking changes
  • Why: Loosely coupling components for safer local changes
  • When: Any scenario where there is no central control


Conclusions Erik Wilde: What Why When Versioning Matters: Tips for API Design, Description, and Documentation
